qas.question: What does glass lack, allowing it to be transparent?
What force gives glass its surface texture?
What, in contrast to glass, doesn't let light pass through?
What type of glass absorbs some light?
What does glass lack, allowing it to be polycrystalline?
What force gives glass its rigid crystal geometries?
What, in contrast to glass, doesn't absorb light?
What type of glass absorbs molecules of supercooled liquid?
What do individual crystallites not contain?

context: Glass is in widespread use largely due to the production of glass compositions that are transparent to visible light. In contrast, <a2_0><b6_0>polycrystalline materials<b6_0/><a2_0/> do not generally transmit visible light. The individual crystallites may be transparent, but their facets (grain boundaries) reflect or scatter light resulting in diffuse reflection. Glass does not contain the <a0_0><b4_0><b8_0>internal subdivisions<b8_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> associated with grain boundaries in polycrystals and hence does not scatter light in the same manner as a polycrystalline material. The surface of a glass is often smooth since during glass formation the molecules of the supercooled liquid are not forced to dispose in rigid crystal geometries and can follow <a1_0><b5_0>surface tension<b5_0/><a1_0/>, which imposes a microscopically smooth surface. These properties, which give glass its clearness, can be retained even if glass is partially light-absorbing—i.e., <a3_0><b7_0>colored<b7_0/><a3_0/>.
